body: Concurrency: Built-in support for concurrency with goroutines and channels
Go Info.description: Provides general information about the Go programming language.

body: // To run this program, use: `go run filename.go`
Go Entry Point.description: Creates the entry point of a Go application.

Go Mathematical Operators.description: Lists the mathematical operators in Go.

body: Go is a statically typed language.
- int, int8, int16, int32, int64: Signed integers
- uint, uint8, uint16, uint32, uint64: Unsigned integers
- rune: Alias for int32 (represents a Unicode code point)
- [10]int: Array of integers with fixed size 10
- map[K]V: Map with key type K and value type V
- struct { Field1 int; Field2 string; }: Custom data structure with named fields
- interface{}: Interface type representing any type
- chan int: Channel for sending and receiving integers
- func(int) string: Function type taking an int and returning a string
- error: Interface type for error handling

Go List Type.description: The Go slice type, commonly used as a list.

Go Null Type.description: The Go nil value, representing the absence of a value.

Go Dynamic Type.description: The Go interface{} type, representing any type.

Go Create Variable.description: Creates a variable in Go using the var keyword

body: //   - Can be declared without initialization (zero value is assigned).
//   - Short variable declaration and type inference.
//   - Use for values that should remain constant.
// - Use 'var' for package-level variables or when explicit type declaration is desired.
// - Use ':=' for most variable declarations within blocks.
// - Use 'const' for values that are known at compile time.
// - This is a basic structure; adjust based on project complexity and preferences.
Go Project Structure (High-Level).description: Explains a high-level project structure for Go.

body: //     - Contains source code for rendering features.
//     - Contains source code for physics features.
//     - Contains source code for networking features.
// - This approach promotes modularity and is suitable for larger projects.
Go Project Structure (Feature/Module).description: Explains a feature/module-based source directory organization for Go.

body: // Recommended Go Source Directory Organization (File Type):
// - This approach can be helpful for smaller projects or specific use cases.
Go Project Structure (File Type).description: Explains a file type-based source directory organization for Go.

body: // In Go, functions do not support default argument values in definitions.
Go Function Args.description: Creates a function with arguments in Go, with a note about default argument values.

body: // Go does not support named arguments in function definitions.
Go Function Named Args.description: Go does not support named arguments in function definitions.

body: // Go does not support function literals (anonymous functions) with a return type.
Go Function Literal.description: Creates a function literal (anonymous function) in Go.

body: // Function with arguments: func FunctionName(arg1 type1, arg2 type2, ...) returnType { ... }
// Note: Go does not support named arguments in function definitions.
